data.title: [Trivia] How many stations? And when does one station become two?
data.meta_description:
Coming out of other threads, a couple of questions:

1. What is the total number of stations in the country, not only on National Rail, but also TfL (London...
data.text:
Coming out of other threads, a couple of questions:

1. What is the total number of stations in the country, not only on National Rail, but also TfL (London Underground, DLR, Tramlink), other Metros (etc) and preserved railways in GB, and also Northern (or even all) Ireland? (Ideally broken down by system)

2. Relevant to this is when does one station become two (or vice versa)? In most cases stations are obviously just one, but there are places where it isn't obvious whether what is there should be counted as one station or two, or even more? Either on a single system - e.g on LU how many stations is Bank/Monument? or Hammersmith? - or where two systems meet, and they both list a station - is it one station used by both? or two conjoined (to be listed/counted as one or two?)? or seperate stations? What makes the difference between one station and two? (or for places like Paddington or King's Cross/St Pancras (now or in the past), even more?)

This is the list that i have of all stations:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

RECENTLY CLOSED STATIONS - (13):

MAINLINE - NATIONAL RAIL - (12):

• Altnabreac

• Angel Road

• Barlaston

• IBM Halt

• Manchester United Football Ground

• Newhaven Marine

• Norton Bridge

• Redcar British Steel

• Sampford Courtenay

• Stanlow And Thornton

• Teesside Airport

• Wedgwood

TRAM - EDINBURGH TRAM - (1):

• York Place

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MAINLINE - NATIONAL RAIL - (2580):

There are 2580 National Rail stations that actually have a passenger service. So the number i go by is 2580 as they actually have trains. The few stations that have recently been closed are shown at the top of my list.

So in total broken down by system:

Mainline - National Rail - 2580

Mainline - Northern Ireland Railways - 54

Mainline - Irish Rail - 145

Metro - Docklands Light Railway - 45

Metro - Glasgow Subway - 15

Metro - London Underground - 272

Metro - Tyne & Wear Metro - 60

Tram - Blackpool Tram - 38

Tram - Croydon Tramlink - 39

Tram - Dublin Luas - 67

Tram - Edinburgh Tram - 23

Tram - Manchester Metrolink - 99

Tram - Nottingham Express Transit - 50

Tram - Sheffield Supertram - 50

Tram - West Midlands Metro - 33

As mentioned this solely includes stations that actually have a service. It does not include stations under construction or closed stations or stations where service has been suspended.

Preserved railways are much more complicating. I am currently trying to create a list but it is more complex. Many have stations which are closed or only used on certain occasions or have been suspended since covid. Also it depends on what you include. Are you just including standard gauge or also narrow gauge or even the dozens of miniature railways. Then do you include the museums that have short running lines with platforms. So adding the heritage railways complicates it a lot.

Regarding joint stations it can be complicating. I count Bank Monument and Edgware Road and Hammersmith and Paddington all as two stations as that is what TFL officially does. With the latter three they are definitely seperate as you have to leave the station to get to the other station of the same name. But with Bank Monument it is really just one station as it is all connected underground. So it is a bit of a grey area.

To get to the London Underground's officially recognised total of 272 stations, Bank and Monument are considered two, Edgware Road is counted as two (District/Circle/Ham&City and Bakerloo), Hammersmith is counted as two (Circle/Ham&City and District/Piccadilly) and Paddington is counted as two (Bakerloo/Circle/District and Circle/Ham&City).

These 4 make sense given they're quite separate at street level too (in fact the Hammersmiths and the Edgware Roads have no connection without going via a public road; and the Paddingtons have no behind-the-barrier link, though the connection can be made entirely within Paddington mainline station). They all make sense in terms of both the physical situation and the history of being separate lines/developments initially. In the case of the Edgware Roads, I'm surprised they've never tried changing the name of one of them, as with the two Shepherds Bushes. (Which have always been indisputably 2 stations.)

And don't forget Ealing Broadway as well! I'm sure LU always used to count [still do?] that as the District and Central being separate, despite the joint entrance/access. I think the Central was even seen as being more or less part of the main line station there at one stage, with the District being a different animal.

Regarding joint stations it can be complicating. I count Bank Monument and Edgware Road and Hammersmith and Paddington all as two stations as that is what TFL officially does. With the latter three they are definitely seperate as you have to leave the station to get to the other station of the same name. But with Bank Monument it is really just one station as it is all connected underground. So it is a bit of a grey area.

Strange really that the only one of these with more than one name is the only one which has complete behind-the-barrier interconnections.
